subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit automatically
msgSnippet: ... How does this work for something that isn t a primitive type like int, boolean, or even String? If I got you right, you throw a lot of inputs at the
messageBody:
On Monday 21 June 2004 17:51, albsavoia wrote:
> These
> observations are in the form of Java boolean valued assertions. For
> example:
>
> File.canWrite() == true
>
> Or
> File.getPath().equals("C:\foo\bar")
>
> Or
> File.list().length == 14

How does this work for something that isn't a primitive type like int,
boolean, or even String?

If I got you right, you throw a lot of inputs at the methods to be tested,
and try to come up with boundary values.
Why do I need this?
Consider some multiply(int, int) method.
Every programmer knows that numeric variables can overflow, so I would
neither document that nor expect the code to somehow having a guard
against this. This is IMHO the job of the VM (throwing something like an
ArithmeticException).

> Combined with Agitator's ability to automatically generate very
> relevant test data and achieve very high code coverage automatically

How is it "automatic" if I have to check the test data / assertions
manually?
If the test data is always boundary conditions (e.g. always pass null
instead of a real object) this will break my code in many places, but I
do not want to check for null each time. Passing null is a programming
error made by whatever code calls my code. If the tool still bogs me
about every method because my code crashed when null was used, the tool
becomes useless. Like those warning labels "Floor may be slippery when
wet"... yeah, I know that.

Robert
